unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: How Many Peas in a Pod?
question_text:
Granny Green owned a huge farm and grew thousands of pea plants. She read that there are $5$ or $6$ peas in a pod on average and she was sure her pods contained more peas than that. She randomly sampled $40$ of her pea pods and decided to do a one-sample t-test to show that the mean number of peas in her pods were higher than the claimed average.
The answer choices below contain both the alternative hypothesis for her test as well as a statement about the condition(s) she needs to verify. Four of the answers contain something wrong, only one answer is correct. Which one?

choices.text:
$H_{a}: \mu>6$
She failed to meet the condition(s) for independence.

$H_{a}: p>6$
She did meet the condition(s) for independence.

$H_{a}: \mu>6$
She failed to meet the condition(s) for showing that the sampling distribution was approximately normal.

$H_{a}: \bar{x}>6$
She did meet the condition(s) for showing that the sampling distribution was approximately normal.

$H_{a}: \mu>6$
Her population of peas were more than $10$ times greater than the size of her sample.

solution:
Solution

First, the alternative hypothesis needs to state that Granny Green believes her peas would have greater than $6$ peas in a pod. Because she is using a one-sample t-test for a mean, she would need to use the population parameter, $\mu$, in her hypothesis; it would be written as $H_{a}: \mu>6$.

To verify conditions two general topics must be addressed: checking for independence and checking for an approximation of normality for the sampling distribution of $\bar{x}$.

To check for independence Granny G. must sample randomly, which it says she did, and she must choose a sample which is at least $10$ times greater in size than her sample. Since her sample is $40$, and since she has thousands of pea plants, then this condition is met.

To check for an approximation of normality for the sampling distribution of $\bar{x}$, Granny Green simply must have a sample size greater than $30$, which she does. So, this condition is also met.

So, Choice 'E' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect because, though $H_{a}$ is correct, Granny G. did meet the conditions for independence.

Choice 'B' is incorrect because, though the statement about conditions is correct, $H_{a}$ is not because it uses a $p$ instead of a $\mu$.

Choice 'C' is incorrect because, though $H_{a}$ is correct, Granny G. did meet the conditions for showing that the sampling distribution was approximately normal.

Choice 'E' is incorrect because, though the statement about conditions is correct, $H_{a}$ is not because it uses an $ \bar{x}$ instead of a $\mu$.
